definition: William A.P. Martin (1827-1916), American missionary who lived 62 years in China between 1850 and 1916, and helped found many Chinese colleges, first president of Peking University
fourth of the ten Heavenly Stems 十天干[shi2 tian1 gan1]/fourth in order/letter "D" or Roman "IV" in list "A, B, C", or "I, II, III" etc/ancient Chinese compass point: 195°/butyl/cubes (of food)
surname Ding
correct/right
good/very/very much
Sir Thomas Francis Wade (1818-1895), British diplomat and sinologist, originator of the Wade-Giles Chinese romanization system
James Legge (1815-1897), Scottish Protestant missionary in Qing China and translator of the Chinese classics into English
the first modern Chinese library established in 1898 by William A.P. Martin 丁韙良|丁韪良, becoming the foundation for Peking University library
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
missionary
Ku Hung-ming or Gu Hongming (1857-1928), Malaysian man of letters, highly regarded for his literary works written mostly in English, and known for his monarchist views
Matteo Ricci (1552-1610), Jesuit missionary and translator in Ming China
a Jesuit/member of Society of Jesus
Xu Jiyu (1795-1873), Chinese geographer
Zhang Yinhuan (1837-1900), late Qing politician and senior Chinese diplomat
sinologist/scholar of Chinese
John Leighton Stuart (1876-1962), second-generation American missionary in China, first president of Yenching University and later United States ambassador to China
the Qing dynasty equivalent of the Foreign Office
Xue Fucheng (1838-1894), Qing official and progressive political theorist
Jonathan D Spence (1936-), distinguished British US historian of China, author of The search for modern China 追尋現代中國|追寻现代中国
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
